content:
I wasn't really motivated to manually implement a sampling technique - sometimes the laziness is just too strong - but took it instead as a nice opportunity to learn more numpy/scipy techniques.
So numpy.polyfit and scipy.optimize.curve_fit are now two new tools in my toolkit :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: you can learn a lot by solving this

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle.  We talked about the Sine function test cases and my independent solution is working very well now.  Good stuff.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very clear description with all necessary details in place.
Hard test cases that required an optimized and well thought out approximation.
Original, although some puzzles look similar on the surface, this requires a very different approach and solution.
I like all the possible help links, examples, and hints to make this a learning experience
The variables need to be formatted in the statement.

The exponential function is giving me some issues.

Issue 1:
Testing a non-integer b gives rise to a complex number y, so somehow I have to force b to be integer when training/testing...
return lambda x: a ** (x + int(b)) + c

Issue 2:
This arises in the last two sets of tests and validators, where one pair of data involves x = 0.
ZeroDivisionError: 0.0 cannot be raised to a negative power.

Not sure whether the player should tackle these issues (which, in my opinion, should not be the focus of this puzzle), or whether the puzzle should be revised in any way?
Blabbage discovered a cheat so I'm reworking.  thanks @Blabbage!

After solving it I think it is classified correctly as "Hard". I don't have any experience in function fitting, and did not look at any videos or tutorials, but did manage to solve it anyway.

I think it is ready to go out of WIP. I am ready to approve...
looks great

difficulty reference puzzle https://www.codingame.com/training/expert/binary-neural-network---part-2
@5DNIL also suggested this puzzle be classified as very hard.  Please respond in this thread if you have opinions about difficulty
@ninjadip suggested the name "CG's Next Top Model" lol.  I like it.  Name changed
I suggest even very hard. You need a lot of mathematical knowledge and algorithms to be able to solve it. ML is a grad course. However the problem is really interesting.

I'm suggesting a difficulty of Hard because it's got that 'hidden' step of having to solve for the parameters first without any feedback if you are on the right track then predict the model.  So even though there are plenty of test cases and a detailed description, it is going to be really hard for someone to debug if they don't have a clear idea of how to implement the hidden steps and test it themselves.
The train and test data sets have been randomly generated then checked to make sure that the preferred model error is significantly less than any of the other models.

Just to clarify, I suggested that this puzzle could be either hard or very hard, depending on whether there were/would be any significantly harder puzzles in this area. In addition, I hadn't tried to solve the puzzle yet, so it'd be unfair for me to have an exact judgement at this stage.
Thanks!  That's great.  I'm eager to see your solution

a^(x+b)+c is a complex number if a is negative.  To fix this the equation is now "f(x) = abs(a)^(x+b) + c".  Thanks.

as far as 0^-1 being zero, you'll have to catch that overflow and handle it gracefully.
Done.  Thanks
Glad to hear!  LazyMammal also used libraries to solve this.  Totally valid.

Thank you.

Now I have a working solution in Python (without adding any test data of my own). My solution may fail when I set the number of training steps to 10,000, but it succeeds (at least on the couple of runs I have) when the number is increased to 15,000.

I will await your feedback regarding my solution I sent in private chat, if you think it solves the problem in a way where you do not need to change the input/output, then I will approve. Just to make sure I really did solve it, the way it was intended to.
Thanks.  I see that your solution was able to solve this without needing the test set.  I've added one more test case that will challenge a solution that only uses the training set.
I sent you a new version, however it does fail 1/3 of the time I will try again later...

Now that I've got a working solution, I believe "hard" is probably a suitable classification.
I'm wondering what might be added to this puzzle to increase its difficulty (for the purpose of being a reference point, or even as an idea for another puzzle). Some random ideas below:
A wider range of possible parameters?
Larger data sets?
A third data set, which the coder has to judge whether it fits the same function as the first (training) and second (testing) data sets?
Outlier handling?
More advanced aspects of modelling in machine learning?
